import React from 'react'; import '../Duties.css'; import Navbar from './Navbar'; import Footer from './Footer'; export default function Duty6() { return ( <>

Fundamental Duty 6: Value and Preserve Our Rich Heritage

Article 51A(f) - Safeguarding India's civilizational legacy

🧩 Comprehensive Understanding

Article 51A(f) establishes a civic obligation to protect India's multifaceted heritage:

  • Tangible Heritage: Monuments, archaeological sites, artifacts
  • Intangible Heritage:
    • Traditional knowledge systems (Ayurveda, Yoga)
    • Performing arts (classical dances, music)
    • Oral traditions and folk arts
  • Natural Heritage: Sacred groves, ecological sites
  • Living Heritage:
    • Handicrafts and artisan traditions
    • Culinary traditions
    • Festivals and rituals

This duty connects modern citizens with their civilizational roots while adapting traditions for contemporary relevance.

📖 Detailed Explanation

The constitutional framework for heritage preservation includes:

  • Legal Protections:
    • Ancient Monuments Act, 1958
    • Antiquities Act, 1972
    • Biological Diversity Act, 2002
    • Geographical Indications Act, 1999
  • Institutional Mechanisms:
    • Archaeological Survey of India (ASI)
    • National Archives
    • INTACH (Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage)
    • UNESCO World Heritage Sites program
  • Citizen Participation:
    • Adopt a Heritage scheme
    • Community museums
    • Digital archiving initiatives

📜 Historical Context

This duty emerged from:

  • Colonial Era Concerns:
    • Large-scale export of antiquities during British rule
    • Rediscovery of India's past by Orientalists
  • Post-Independence Challenges:
    • Neglect of heritage sites
    • Urbanization pressures
    • Commercial exploitation of cultural symbols
  • Constitutional Response:
    • 42nd Amendment (1976) during cultural revival movements
    • Inspired by Tagore's vision of cultural nationalism
    • Complementary to Directive Principles (Article 49)

🏛️ Judicial Interpretations

  • M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (1987) : Established "polluter pays" principle for heritage site protection. [AIR 1987 SC 1086]
  • Rajeev Mankotia v. Secretary to President (1996) : Upheld protection of Viceregal Lodge as heritage property. [1997 SCC (1) 441]
  • Intellectuals Forum v. State of AP (2006) : Balanced development with heritage conservation. [(2006) 3 SCC 549]

🔍 Contemporary Challenges

  • Climate change impacts on heritage structures
  • Digital preservation vs. physical conservation
  • Commercialization vs. authenticity debates
  • Repatriation of stolen artifacts
  • Urban development vs. heritage conservation
); }
